title: Fructose in Fruits
content: Natural fruits have much less fructose in an individual fruit. Fruit juice is made from multiple fruits. An orange has 6-8 grams of fructose, closer to 6 g of fructose and some glucose. Certain fruits that are high in sugar include mangoes, figs, dates. Figs are very enriched in fructose and are probably something that should be avoided. Apples, pears, plums tend to be fairly high, around 9-10 grams. Bananas have a fair amount of fructose, but it’s probably in the range of 6-8 grams. Most fruits are between 3-9 g, 10 g max, with the average being 4-6 g. Some fruits have much less sugar— kiwi and berries (strawberries and blueberries).

title: Fructose and Metabolic Syndrome
content: A study was conducted where people were given a low sugar diet that was low in refined sugar and low in high fructose corn syrup. One group got natural fruit, but was low sugar and low fructose. The other group was restricted too. They found equivalent improvement in metabolic syndrome in both groups. The presence of natural fruit did not block the ability of the low sugar diet to improve metabolic syndrome.

title: Added Sugar in Foods
content: Added sugar is when a food has sucrose or high fructose corn syrup. These are typically the most common agents that are added to the food. This is not the sugar naturally present in the food; it’s deliberately added to make it taste sweeter.

title: Fructose Intake and Intestinal Protection
content: The intestine acts as a shield for 4-6 grams of fructose. Eating 4-5 g of fructose in a fruit is okay because the intestine’s going to provide protection. In addition, there is fiber in a natural fruit and that slows the absorption so the concentration of fructose that goes to the liver is lower. This results in less ATP depletion.

title: Dried Fruits and Fructose
content: Dried fruit still has all the fructose, but a lot of the good things are removed. Dried fruit is sort of like candy.

title: Research Focus
content: The primary focus in research has been on the mechanisms causing kidney disease. This research led to an interest in the connection between fructose (and fructose metabolism) and obesity, diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, and metabolic disease.

title: Publications and Lectures
content: The individual has over 700 publications in JAMA, New England Journal of Medicine, Science, etc. They have lectured across 40 countries and authored two books, including The Fat Switch.

title: Funding
content: The research has been funded extensively by the National Institute of Health (NIH).
